ALP/Cougaar External Agent Liaison Capability.

See:
          Description

Packages
com.prc.alp.liaison Defines the constants used throughout the ALP/Cougaar external agent liaison capability.
com.prc.alp.liaison.acl Provides parsing support for messages received from external agents.
com.prc.alp.liaison.admin Provides utility support for the administration of ALP/Cougaar liaisons with external agents through a JavaSpace-based interface.
com.prc.alp.liaison.adminGUI Provides a GUI for administration of ALP/Cougaar liaisons with external agents through a JavaSpace-based interface.
com.prc.alp.liaison.assets Provides definitions of assets and property groups used by ALP/Cougaar agents for external agent liaisons; not currently in active use.
com.prc.alp.liaison.interact Provides facilities for creating and engaging in interactions involving the transfer or exchange of information with external agents.
com.prc.alp.liaison.plugin Provides primary functions for enabling ALP/Cougaar PlugIns to manage liaisons with external agents and agent societies, and to check their liaison permissions.
com.prc.alp.liaison.retsina Provides tailored Web page parsing capabilities for RETSINA InfoAgents.
com.prc.alp.liaison.test Provides simple facilities for testing the ALP/Cougaar external agent liaison capability and setting up test data.
com.prc.alp.liaison.util Provides utilities for working with a JavaSpace.
com.prc.alp.liaison.weather Provides a demonstration capability for an ALP/Cougaar cluster to engage in a liaison with an external RETSINA InfoAgent (via the CoABS Grid) for the purpose of acquiring weather forecasts.

 

ALP/Cougaar External Agent Liaison Capability.

Overview

This collection of software provides both a general mechanism and a specific demonstration enabling an ALP/Cougaar society to interoperate with external agents in other societies through the establishment of liaisons (persistent interactive relationships). These agent-oriented liaisons meet the needs of ALP/Cougaar society agents (clusters) by allowing them to dynamically locate and use the services of agents outside their own society. For example, a logistics transportation planner that has run short of taskable assets may choose to invoke the services of an external commercial shipping service through an interactive agent. Or it may contact a web crawler agent to subscribe to useful information that is updated dynamically. Alternatively, a liaison may meet the needs of external agents, by allowing them to coordinate their own service needs with an ALP/Cougaar society.

Beyond providing a core technology that makes liaisons possible, this software collection includes JavaSpace-based facilities for administration of liaisons (controlling which ones are permissible), and a working demonstration of a pre-existing ALP/Cougaar society using liaisons with a pre-existing external agent society through the CoABS Grid. Note that there are some non-Cougaar components required for this demonstration; see the caveats.

More detailed information about this capability can be found in a set of PowerPoint slides presented to the ALP community workshop in December, 2000. (Use this version if your browser or system does not support direct PowerPoint display.) Some new capabilities have been developed since this presentation was developed, but the information it contains is still correct. Questions of any kind are welcomed by the principal author, Brandon L. Buteau.

Core Technology

The fundamental technology underyling the liaison capability is built on a small set of classes and interfaces that are designed to make agent-oriented liaisons flexible and reusable in the ALP/Cougaar context. The solution includes components that address these needs by factoring out common features of liaisons at different levels.

Interactions

In the most abstract sense, a liaison between agents requires the transfer of information between them, sometimes in one direction only, but usually in both directions. These transfers can be divided over time into distinct episodes or groupings called interactions. A simple interaction involving two agents might follow a query/response pattern, while a complex interaction involving multiple agents might implement an extended RFP/proposal/negotiation/award protocol executed over distinct time phases. However, no matter what the pattern, an agent can only a perform a few distinct generic actions as part of an interaction:
  • it can set up or initialize information required for the interaction,
  • it can send information to or receive information from other agents (perhaps many times during the interaction), or
  • it can terminate the interaction normally or abnormally and utilize any final results, if appropriate.
The liaison capability facilitates these actions and the transitions between them with the Interaction class, which provides an independently-threaded state-driven engine capable of performing both synchronous and asynchronous interactions of arbitrary complexity.

Interactors

While an Interaction as a class represents what is abstract and in common among all agent-oriented information exchanges, instances of interactions must be highly differentiated somehow, in order to allow for the huge range of variability in the content, control, and communication methods required for specific exchanges. The liaison capability encapsulates this differentiability with the Interactor interface.

An Interactor is any object that implements specialized versions of the generic actions performed during an interaction, along with some decision logic that controls the order of those actions. In effect, interactors contain the pieces of a coupling for connecting the internal ALP/Cougaar environment with an external agent. Each specialized interactor acts as a kind of plug-in (not in the sense of an ALP/Cougaar PlugIn) to the generic Interaction engine; the interaction instance provides a standardized control framework, while the interactor instance provides a customized, appropriate behavior pattern. Together they form a flexible structure for information exchange.

Deputies

An ALP/Cougaar cluster may be supporting several tasks concurrently, and so it may also need to engage in several liaisons with multiple external agents at the same time. To limit what a PlugIn developer needs to know in order to create liaisons, and to simplify the establishment and control of multiple liaisons, the liaison capability encapsulates a number of higher-level functions in an object called a LiaisonDeputy. These deputies are responsible for representing an ALP/Cougaar cluster as an agent to some external agent society, and for providing interaction housekeeping support. A LiaisonDeputy is able to:
  • establish initial contact with a particular type of external agent society
  • maintain information relevant to active interactions with that society
  • check for possible timeouts associated with active interactions.
Finally, each LiaisonDeputy determines which interactions are permissible by consulting a JavaSpace-based liaison administration interface (see below). Depending on configuration settings, a deputy may block or suspend attempts to engage in disallowed interactions.

Liaison Administration

Once it is possible for an ALP/Cougaar society to dynamically identify and interact with external agents, the issue of liaison administration must be addressed. Administration in this context refers to the management of liaison permissions. It is clearly undesirable to allow any ALP/Cougaar agent to interact with any external agent that may happen to be accessible; there must be some mechanism that both allows society administrators to specify and change what kinds of interactions are acceptable, and allows deputies to rapidly check those permissions to control attempted interactions.

The liaison capability provides an experimental implementation of this mechanism built upon a Jini JavaSpace service. The JavaSpace stores information about ALP/Cougaar and external agents, and records whether or not individual ALP/Cougaar agents can initiate or respond to interactions with specific external agents. These permissions are changed in a persistent and transaction-safe manner under human control through a GUI that displays both an ALP society and an external agent society side by side.

See the com.prc.alp.liaison.admin and com.prc.alp.liaison.adminGUI packages for more details on liaison administration.

Liaison Demonstration

To demonstrate how liaisons can be an effective means of expanding the scope of ALP/Cougaar societies, the liaison capability includes a working example of a liaison between a pre-existing ALP/Cougaar society (the Litton TASC Air Expeditionary Force [AEF] society) and a pre-existing external agent society (CMU's Reusable Environment for Task Structured Intelligent Network Agents [RETSINA]). Interactions are mediated through DARPA's Control of Agent-Based Systems (CoABS) Grid, which provides its own facilities for supporting interoperability between heterogeneous agent frameworks.

Functionally, this demonstration shows the potential impact of weather forecast information on transportation planning; weather information had previously been unavailable to ALP/Cougaar societies. New PlugIns were added to an existing AEF cluster (GlobalAir) that has some transportation planning responsibilities. Without modifying the original GlobalAir code, these new PlugIns:

  • generate weather forecast requirements from existing transportation tasks
  • extend the GlobalAir plan to include weather requirements correlated across multiple tasks
  • interact with an external RETSINA agent that can extract weather forecast information from a commercial Web site
  • receive the externally-supplied forecast information and modify previously-established transportation plans.
In addition, the demonstration includes an ALP/Cougaar PSP GUI that can display the before/after impact of the weather forecasts on AEF transportation plans. See the com.prc.alp.liaison.weather package for more details on this demonstration.

Caveats on Use

The liaison capability is available as a compatible extension of DARPA's Cougaar software, and all components in the com.prc.alp.liaison package and its subordinates are subject to the Cougaar open source license (available through the Cougaar Web site). However, the included liaison demonstration is dependent upon non-Cougaar software that is separately licensed and available from different sources:
  • Information about the CoABS Grid is available through the Grid Web site.
  • Information about RETSINA is available through its home page or through its project coordinator, Joseph Giampapa.
  • Information about the Litton TASC AEF society is not publicly available at this time. Contact Chris Allen at TASC to inquire further.
